Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task sits on the critical path for an external delivery promised to a client.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story: I stared at my screen, the clock ticking louder in my mind than in reality. As a colleague, I knew the task in front of me was crucial—my part was the linchpin for the client delivery, and everyone was counting on me to finish by Friday. The pressure was mounting; I could almost feel the weight of my teammates’ expectations pressing on my shoulders. But as a software developer, I also felt the pull of the upcoming brainstorming session. Product had invited us to help shape the next big feature, and even though attendance was technically optional, I knew my input would matter. I wanted to be part of the creative process, to have a say in what we’d build next, and to show I was invested in the team’s future. The two roles tugged at me from opposite sides—one demanding focus and speed, the other asking for vision and collaboration. My mind raced, torn between the urgent and the important, knowing that whatever I chose, something would have to give.
